unnormalised: Hey everyone, getting ready to rent a place? Let's talk rental agreements, because trust me, you don't want to learn about them the hard way!
normalised: Hey everyone, getting ready to rent a place? Let's talk rental agreements, because trust me, you don't want to learn about them the hard way!

unnormalised: So, a rental agreement, also known as a lease agreement, is basically a contract between you (the tenant) and the landlord. It spells out the dos and don'ts for both parties. Think of it like the rulebook for your home away from home.
normalised: So, a rental agreement, also known as a lease agreement, is basically a contract between you (the tenant) and the landlord. It spells out the dos and don'ts for both parties. Think of it like the rulebook for your home away from home.

unnormalised: What should it cover? Well, definitely the obvious: rent amount (Rs. 10,000 a month, anyone?), due date, late fee policy (nobody wants to be slapped with extra charges!). Then there's the security deposit – how much is it (usually a month or two's rent, right?) and under what conditions will you get it back when you move out of your 1 BHK in Andheri.
normalised: What should it cover? Well, definitely the obvious: rent amount (rupees ten thousand a month, anyone?), due date, late fee policy (nobody wants to be slapped with extra charges!). Then there's the security deposit – how much is it (usually a month or two's rent, right?) and under what conditions will you get it back when you move out of your one B H K in Andheri.

unnormalised: Important things to consider: duration of the agreement (usually 11 months in India to avoid more complex registration procedures), repair responsibilities (who fixes the leaky faucet, you or Dr. Sharma, the landlord?), rules about pets (Mr. Mittal down the hall *really* hates barking, apparently), and any restrictions on modifications to the property (can you paint that depressing beige wall a nice, cheerful yellow?). Also, make sure it clearly states the built up area in sq ft.

Also, make sure it clearly states the built up area in square feet.

unnormalised: Don’t just blindly sign what’s put in front of you. Read it carefully! Ask questions! Negotiate! It’s your right. If you're unsure, it’s always a good idea to get a lawyer to look it over. It’s better to spend a little money upfront than to get into a legal mess later. This isn't a Bollywood movie, you need actual legal docs!
